text:
I wanted to create a CGI script that allowed me to do a custom directory
listing, but I don't have enough information to do this if I set, for example:

DirectoryIndex /cgi-bin/dirlist.cgi

There is just no way to get all the information needed to accurately and
securely list the directory. This is especially a problem if you use the Alias
directive.

mod_autoindex should have a directive that it can create a template of some sort
that you can pass to a CGI script. The template would contain the names of all
the files, and their information, along with the name of the current directory,
and anything else need to create your own custom directory listings. Example:

CustomListingScript /cgi-bin/dirlist.cgi

text:
This is already possible via both mod_perl and mod_python. Setting as enhancement; I'd tend to 
suggest that you'd find either of those products more suitable for this.

creator: netdemonz@yahoo.com
text:
I'll check out mod_perl as an alternative in the mean time, though allowing
another method, for instance a shared data file or extra environ variables would
mean that it could also be used in other languages that don't yet have
mod_support in apache, though you could still use mod_perl and invoke them from
that script. I'm a bit picky and most people don't care, but I didn't like the
lack of control I had over the way the directory list appeared. Thanks for the
information. I think still as a benefit for those that don't use mod_perl, etc,
that this would still be a good thing to have.
I'd like to hack this in myself. How do I get started?
creator: netdemonz@yahoo.com
netdemonz@yahoo.com
text:
I'd also like to allow it to be able to also allow the client to modify the way
it looks. For instance, if you are browsing in a client, the client should be
able to send some kind of header that allows you to send out something to the
client so it can recieve some genetic data and then layout itself the directory
listing in a fancy manner such as Internet Explorer does on FTP servers.

The CGI script should also be able to grab multiple directories, so it can do
things like allow expandable tree lists.

I'd suggest that you want to write your own module, I don't see that we'd want
to include this functionality in what is, after all, a very simple module.
Certainly use autoindex as a base, but go from there.
